pageData.text: Connective tissue is very common in the body and has a lot of different appearances and functions. All <button class='glossary-text'>connective tissues</button> have an <button class='glossary-text'>extracellular matrix</button> containing protein fibers. <button class='glossary-text'>Cartilage</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>bone</button> are specialized connective tissues in which the matrix is rigid. This makes them well suited for their role in supporting and protecting the body. In this investigation, you will learn to identify the difference between compact and <button class='glossary-text'>spongy bones</button>, including the different internal components. The three types of cartilage will also be examined.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Comparing Cartilages - 15 minutes
Activity 2: Comparing Bones - 15 minutes

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Recognize and describe the external and internal components of <button class='glossary-text'>bone</button> tissue.
Compare and contrast the different internal components of <button class='glossary-text'>compact bone</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>spongy bone</button>.
Identify the three types of <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>, list their locations, and explain their functions.

pageData.text: When you were first born, you had around 300 . As an adult, on the other hand, you now have only 206 bones. What happened to the 100 or so bones you used to have?Most of the bones you had a birth were comprised entirely of rather than hard bone; this feature allows a fetus to be flexible within the confines of a mother’s womb, as well as during the process of childbirth through the narrow birth canal. As you grew through infancy into childhood and adulthood, some of your cartilaginous bones fused together. For example, an infant has several soft spots, or fontanelles, on their head where multiple skull bones have yet to fuse together. An adult skull does not have these soft spots; however, the sites of fusion are identifiable on the skull. The fusing of bones during development reduces the total number of bones present in adulthood. In addition to fusing, your growing skeleton changed in composition. The flexible cartilage of your infant skeleton transitioned to hard bone as cells called covered, and then ultimately replaced, the cartilage with bone.

pageData.desc: A model of a human skull with the cranial bones each a different color.
pageData.altText: A model of a human skull with the cranial bones each a different color.

pageData.text: Made up of bone and <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>, the human skeletal system has many important functions, including support, movement, protection of internal organs, blood cell production, and mineral storage.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Digestive System

pageData.subTitle: Skeleton
pageData.text: The adult human body has 206 bones and can be divided into 2 parts—the <button class='glossary-text'>axial skeleton</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>appendicular skeleton</button>.
The axial skeleton includes bones of the skull, , , , , and , totaling 80 bones.
The appendicular skeleton includes the 126 bones of the shoulders, <button class='glossary-text'>pelvis</button>, and upper and lower extremities.

pageData.subTitle: Bone Tissue
pageData.text: There are 2 types of bone tissue. Compact bone is hard, dense, mineralized tissue that gives bone its strength. It usually surrounds spongy bone tissue. Spongy bone is a porous layer of tissue that makes bone lightweight. Its spaces usually contain blood vessels and bone marrow, a soft tissue that produces blood cells.

pageData.subTitle: Cartilage
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cartilage</button> is a flexible connective tissue that forms the embryonic skeleton. Most is ossified into bone during fetal and childhood development. In adults, cartilage is found at movable joints, and in the ear, nose, trachea, and other structures. It also connects the ribs and sternum.
<button class='glossary-text'>Connective tissues</button> are present all throughout the human body and have a wide variety of functions. They:

text: Establish a framework that anchors other types of tissues and allows movement

pageData.text: Because of these diverse functions, the appearance of connective tissue can vary widely. All connective tissue has cells and an <button class='glossary-text'>extracellular matrix</button> (ECM) containing protein fibers. They are also highly specialized and are surrounded by a fluid known as the <button class='glossary-text'>ground substance</button>.
Since there is such a high amount of variation in the appearance and function of connective tissues, they can be grouped according to their main function:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Fluid connective tissue</button>, such as blood and lymph fluids

Connective tissue proper, which can be grouped by <button class='glossary-text'>loose connective tissue</button> (adipose) and <button class='glossary-text'>dense connective tissue</button> (dense regular).

<button class='glossary-text'>Supporting connective tissue</button>, used for protection and to give form to the body. It is characterized by a firm to rigid ECM, like <button class='glossary-text'>bone</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>.

pageData.text: This investigation focuses on the supporting connective tissue. There are two main types of supporting connective tissue: bone (osseous tissue) and cartilage. In bone tissue, the ECM is by mineral deposits between the ECM proteins. This makes the bone inflexible and hard. The ECM in cartilage is gel-like, which allows the cartilage to flex and maintain some mobility.

<button class='glossary-text'>Cartilage</button> reduces friction and is often located near joints or places where movement is needed. Cartilage covers the ends of long <button class='glossary-text'>bones</button>, attaches the ribs to the sternum, and is found between the vertebrae. It can also be used to form parts of the body, such as ears and the nose. The ECM in cartilage is gel-like, which allows movement of the tissue. Proteins in the ECM, together with the density of extracellular fibers, determine the rigidity of the cartilage. The cells found in the cartilage, the <button class='glossary-text'>chondrocytes</button>, are located inside the ECM and occupy small spaces, or <button class='glossary-text'>lacunae</button>. Cartilage is often surrounded by dense, irregular connective tissue, the <button class='glossary-text'>perichondrium</button>.

pageData.question: This investigation focuses on which type of tissue?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: This investigation focuses on the supporting connective tissues of cartilage and bone.

pageData.question: There are three distinct types of cartilage in the human body, but they all have what common structure to their extracellular matrices (ECM)?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The ECM of cartilage is defined by its gel-like structure, which allows cartilage to flex and maintain some mobility.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since there is such a high amount of variation in the appearance and function of connective tissues, they can be grouped according to their main function. Fluid connective tissue, such as blood and lymph fluids, connective tissue proper, which can be grouped by loose connective tissue (adipose) and dense connective tissue (dense regular), and supporting connective tissue, such as cartilage and bone. In bone tissue, the extracellular matrix (ECM) is calcified by mineral deposits between the ECM proteins. This makes the bone inflexible and hard. The ECM in cartilage is gel-like, which allows the cartilage to flex and maintain some mobility.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since there is such a high amount of variation in the appearance and function of connective tissues, they can be grouped according to their main function. Fluid connective tissue, such as blood and lymph fluids, connective tissue proper, which can be grouped by loose connective tissue (adipose) and dense connective tissue (dense regular), and supporting connective tissue, such as cartilage and bone. In bone tissue, the extracellular matrix (ECM) is calcified by mineral deposits between the ECM proteins. This makes the bone inflexible and hard. The ECM in cartilage is gel-like, which allows the cartilage to flex and maintain some mobility.

pageData.text: The human body contains three distinct types of <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>: the <button class='glossary-text'>hyaline cartilage</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>fibrocartilage</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>elastic cartilage</button>. From these three types, the hyaline cartilage (Figure 1) is the most abundant and has an ECM that contains collagen fibers that are packed very close together. Because of the nature of these fibers and their inability to absorb most commonly used stains, these fibers can be very hard to see in a microscope slide (glassy appearance). Hyaline cartilage is commonly found in joints, where the ribs connect to the sternum, and in the septum of the nose.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Image of hyaline cartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and perichondrium.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Image of hyaline cartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and perichondrium.

pageData.text: The second type of <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button> is <button class='glossary-text'>fibrocartilage</button> (Figure 2). This cartilage has a very dense ECM filled with collagen fibers, which gives it a lot of strength and flexibility. This type of cartilage often functions as a shock absorber between the vertebrae and other areas of the skeletal system that experience impacts.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Image of fibrocartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and fibrous matrix.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Image of fibrocartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and fibrous matrix.

pageData.text: The last type of <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button> is <button class='glossary-text'>elastic cartilage</button> (Figure 3). This type of cartilage contains elastic fibers in the ECM, which often show up as having a purple (dark) tint on slides. These tissue types are found in areas that are able to have some movement or flexibility to them, such as the ear.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Image of elastic cartilage, chondrocytes in lacunae, and elastic fibers in the matrix.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Image of elastic cartilage, chondrocytes in lacunae, and elastic fibers in the matrix.

pageData.question: Why is hyaline cartilage sometimes very hard to see in a microscope slide?

options.text: It is made up of fibers that resist staining.
It is found in areas that have some movement.
It is elastic and loosely structured.
Its cells have too many organelles.
It absorbs a lot of stain and usually looks dark purple.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because of the nature of collagen fibers and their inability to absorb most commonly used stains, these fibers in hyaline cartilage can be very hard to see in a microscope slide.

pageData.question: Where would you find elastic cartilage?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Elastic cartilage is found in areas that can have some movement or flexibility to them, such as the nose or ears.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The human body contains three distinct types of cartilage: hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage, and elastic cartilage. Of these three types, the hyaline cartilage is the most abundant and has an ECM that contains collagen fibers that are packed very closely together, making them difficult to stain. Hyaline cartilage is commonly found in joints, where the ribs connect to the sternum, and in the septum of the nose. The second type of cartilage is fibrocartilage. This type of cartilage often functions as a shock absorber between the vertebrae and other areas of the skeletal system that experience impacts. The last type of cartilage is elastic cartilage. This type of cartilage contains elastic fibers in the ECM, which often show up as having a purple (dark) tint on slides. These tissue types are found in areas that can have some movement or flexibility to them, such as the ear.

img.alt: Figure 1: Image of hyaline cartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and perichondrium.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The human body contains three distinct types of cartilage: hyaline cartilage, fibrocartilage, and elastic cartilage. Of these three types, the hyaline cartilage is the most abundant and has an ECM that contains collagen fibers that are packed very closely together, making them difficult to stain. Hyaline cartilage is commonly found in joints, where the ribs connect to the sternum, and in the septum of the nose. The second type of cartilage is fibrocartilage. This type of cartilage often functions as a shock absorber between the vertebrae and other areas of the skeletal system that experience impacts. The last type of cartilage is elastic cartilage. This type of cartilage contains elastic fibers in the ECM, which often show up as having a purple (dark) tint on slides. These tissue types are found in areas that can have some movement or flexibility to them, such as the ear.

img.alt: Figure 1: Image of hyaline cartilage showing chondrocytes, lacunae, and perichondrium.

pageData.text: , or osseous tissue, is a supportive connective tissue that is characterized by a solid ECM. The ECM contains organic and inorganic minerals, such as calcium phosphate and the protein collagen, that give the bone its strength. Bone supports the body, protects internal organs, provides for muscle attachment, and serves as a calcium reservoir. Many bones have a marrow cavity in which blood cells are formed. (Figure 4) consists of repeating units called . Each osteon consists of concentric layers of the mineralized ECM deposited around a . This canal contains blood vessels and nerves that serve the bone cells. Bone-forming cells, called , deposit the ECM around the central canal.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Image of compact bone showing osteons, lacunae, canaliculi, and central canals.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Image of compact bone showing osteons, lacunae, canaliculi, and central canals.

pageData.text: secrete the ECM and ultimately surround themselves with the mineralized material, forming a pocket called a . Once osteoblasts are surrounded by ECM, the mature cells are called . Narrow connections called extend from lacunae and connect osteocytes to each other and to the . gives the skeletal system its strength and is thickest in areas that either encounter a high level of mechanical stress or need extra protection. In a long , the osteon is in line with the long axis of the bone. This gives the bone the ability to absorb and distribute a lot of force along its axis. The disadvantage of this alignment is that force applied perpendicular to the long axis can break the bone. (Figure 5) is located in areas where shock absorption is more important than strength. It can also be found in areas of the bone where external forces may act on the bone from different directions. Where compact bone is strong mainly in one direction, spongy bone is able to absorb stress from several directions. Spongy bone is also less dense than compact bone, allowing it to deform more and thus absorb the stress. Spongy bone is often located in the ends of long bones. Since the spongy tissue is not aligned in one direction only, the ECM will form a network of fibers going in several directions, called . Spongy bone does not contain any blood vessels in the ECM and will lack the canals for these, which are visible in compact bones.

Red bone marrow is found in the spaces between the trabeculae. Blood vessels are present in the red bone marrow, and any nutrients and waste product will move farther into and out of the trabeculae using diffusion.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Image of spongy bone showing trabeculae and osteocytes inside lacunae.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Image of spongy bone showing trabeculae and osteocytes inside lacunae.

imageData.altText: Image of spongy bone showing trabeculae and osteocytes inside lacunae.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: These dark pockets in the spongy bone are lacunae, which contain mature osteocytes.

pageData.question: Where is spongy bone often found?

options.text: at the ends of long bones
in the middle of the long bones

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Spongy bone is often located at the ends of long bones.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Bone, or osseous tissue, is a supportive connective tissue that is characterized by a solid ECM. The ECM contains organic and inorganic minerals, such as calcium phosphate and the protein collagen, that give the bone its strength. Bone supports the body, protects internal organs, provides muscle attachment, and serves as a calcium reservoir. Many bones have a marrow cavity in which blood cells are formed. Spongy bone is often located at the ends of long bones. Since the spongy tissue is not aligned in one direction only, the ECM will form a network of fibers going in several directions, called trabeculae. Spongy bone does not contain any blood vessels in the ECM and will lack the canals for these, which are visible in compact bones. Both compact bone and spongy bone house their osteocytes in pockets called lacunae.

img.alt: Figure 4: Image of compact bone showing osteons, lacunae, canaliculi, and central canals.

Bone supports the body, protects internal organs, provides muscle attachment, and serves as a calcium reservoir. Many bones have a marrow cavity in which blood cells are formed. Spongy bone is often located at the ends of long bones. Since the spongy tissue is not aligned in one direction only, the ECM will form a network of fibers going in several directions, called trabeculae. Spongy bone does not contain any blood vessels in the ECM and will lack the canals for these, which are visible in compact bones. Both compact bone and spongy bone house their osteocytes in pockets called lacunae.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, you will set up the microscope. In Activity 1, you will place a cartilage slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. You will repeat this process for a second cartilage slide.  Lastly, compare the characteristics of each cartilage type. Place a bone slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. You will repeat this process for a second bone slide. Lastly, compare the characteristics of each bone type.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Introduction to Histology: Cartilage & Bone investigation (item number 580568) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices.Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.Ensure that any broken or discarded microscope slides are disposed of properly. Put them in a hard-sided container (such as a small, sturdy cardboard box) before placing them in the household trash.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Select a work area that is near an electrical outlet if using a corded microscope.
Obtain all needed materials from your kit and those that are needed but not supplied. (Remember: when carrying your microscope, grasp it by the arm and support the base.)
Familiarize yourself with your microscope. Identify its key parts. Consult the instructions that came with your microscope if you have any difficulty finding a specific part.
Note: If your microscope has an oil immersion (100×) objective, identify it, but do not use it during this investigation.

Be aware of your instructor’s directions for documenting your work. You may be asked to draw pictures and either photograph or scan them for submission, or you may need to take pictures through the microscope using a digital camera or mobile device. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, see the following video:

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will observe two different <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button> slides under the microscope and compare their characteristics.
Collect the <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button> slides from the slide set.
Start with the <button class='glossary-text'>hyaline cartilage</button>, and place it on the microscope stage.
Note: Remember, the label should be faceup on the left.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section with well-defined hyaline cartilage. Increase magnification as needed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate <button class='glossary-text'>chondrocytes</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lacunae</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>perichondrium</button>.
In Data Table 1, note what makes this cartilage look different from the other cartilages after comparing it with . Also record the total magnification used.
Return the hyaline cartilage slide to the slide box. Then take the fibrocartilage slide, and place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section with well-defined cartilage. Increase magnification as needed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate chondrocytes, lacunae, and perichondrium.

In Data Table 1, note what makes this cartilage look different from the other cartilages after comparing it with hyaline cartilage. Also record the total magnification used.Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
In Activity 2, you will observe two different <button class='glossary-text'>bone</button> slides under the microscope and compare their characteristics.
Collect the <button class='glossary-text'>bone</button> slides from the slide set.
Start with the mammal <button class='glossary-text'>compact bone</button>; place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that shows the concentric circles well. Increase magnification as needed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate osteon, , , and .
In Data Table 2, note what makes this compact bone look different after comparing it with mammal . Also record the total magnification needed to best view the object.
Return the mammal compact bone slide to the slide box. Then take the mammal spongy bone slide, and place it on the microscope stage.
Center and focus the slide at the lowest power.
Scan through the slide until you come across a section that shows the <button class='glossary-text'>osteocytes</button> well. Increase magnification as needed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take or draw a picture of what you can distinguish, and indicate the osteocyte and the lacunae. Also, record the total magnification used.Total magnification = (eyepiece lens power) x (objective lens power)
In Data Table 2, note what makes this mammal spongy bone look different from the mammal compact bone.

Cover the microscope, and store it for future use.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, you will set up the microscope. In Activity 1, you will place a cartilage slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. You will repeat this process for a second cartilage slide.  Lastly, compare the characteristics of each cartilage type. Place a bone slide on the stage and focus the tissue in the field of view. Next, record an image of the tissue under ideal magnification and identify the structures of the magnified tissue. Then, calculate the total magnification for ideal observation. You will repeat this process for a second bone slide. Lastly, compare the characteristics of each bone type.

How to Handle, Store, and Repair Microscope Slides

data.title: Bone (osseous tissue)
data.content: A specialized type of dense connective tissue with a ground substance containing mineral salts, such as calcium phosphate, and fibers made up of the protein collagen

data.title: Calcified
data.content: Describes tissue in which calcium salts are deposited in the matrix, making the tissue inflexible and hard

data.title: Canaliculi
data.content: The narrow connections that extend from lacunae and connect osteocytes to each other and to the central canal

data.title: Cartilage
data.content: A flexible type of connective tissue with a gel-like extracellular matrix

data.title: Central canal
data.content: A canal in compact bone that contains blood vessels and nerves that serve the bone cells in compound bone

data.title: Chondrocytes
data.content: The cells found in cartilage; they are located inside the extracellular matrix and occupy lacunae

data.title: Compact bone
data.content: The type of bone that is harder and denser than spongy bone, and which forms the “shell” of most bones

data.title: Connective tissues
data.content: The diverse group of tissues that link and support other tissues

data.title: Dense connective tissue
data.content: A type of connective tissue proper that is rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers; also called dense regular connective tissue

data.title: Elastic cartilage
data.content: A type of cartilage that has a very dense extracellular matrix filled with collagen fibers, which gives it a lot of strength and flexibility

data.title: Extracellular matrix
data.content: The network of ground substance and fibers secreted by connective tissue cells, and which is largely responsible for the properties of connective tissues; also called the ECM

data.title: Fibrocartilage
data.content: A type of cartilage that contains elastic fibers in the extracellular matrix that often have a purple (dark) tint on microscope slides

data.title: Fluid connective tissue
data.content: A category of connective tissue that includes blood and lymph fluids

data.title: Ground substance
data.content: A component of extracellular matrices made up of mostly water with added polysaccharide and protein molecules for stability

data.title: Hyaline cartilage
data.content: The most abundant type of cartilage in the human body, and which has an extracellular matrix that contains tightly packed collagen fibers

data.title: Lacuna (plural, lacunae)
data.content: In cartilage, it is a small space in the extracellular matrix and inside which chondrocytes are located; in compound bone, it is a pocket that forms when an osteoblast surrounds itself with its secreted extracellular matrix

data.title: Loose connective tissue
data.content: A type of connective tissue proper that stores fat in adipocytes; also called adipose tissue

data.title: Osteoblasts
data.content: A type of bone tissue cell that forms bone and deposits extracellular matrixc around the central canal

data.title: Osteocytes
data.content: A type of bone tissue cell; they are osteoblasts surrounded by their secreted ECM

data.title: Osteons
data.content: The repeating units of compound bone that consist of concentric layers of mineralized extracellular matrix deposited around a central canal

data.title: Perichondrium
data.content: The dense, irregular connective tissue that often surrounds cartilage

data.title: Spongy bone
data.content: The type of bone tissue that is softer and less dense than compound bone; it is often located in the ends of long bones

data.title: Supporting connective tissue
data.content: A type of connective tissue that protects and gives form to the body; it is characterized by a firm to rigid extracellular matrix, like bone and cartilage

data.title: Trabeculae
data.content: A network of fibers going in several directions in the extracellular matrix of spongy bone
